page.title: 20WOODLESFORD STATION
page.content: The station was opened about 1900 by the L.M.S. Co. with 18 regular staff. It had a private siding to Bentley's Brewery. During the 2nd World War the staff was increased to 26 as all wines & spirits came into brewery and most beer went out by rail. Extra lorries and horses were stabled at Woodlesford to deal with this traffic. There was also a private line to the Water Haigh Colliery and Armitage's Brickworks, thousands of tons of coal, etc. left each week. A considerable amount of specialised oil for aircraft engines left Ragosine Oil Co. by rail every day during the war. The introduction of diesel passenger units with guards taking fares caused the station to become unmanned in 1968. The station is now mainly used by commuters to Leeds, approx. 120 per day, the peak hours being 07.00/0900 and 1600/1800.
